title: I have two judgments & bank levy. Is it too late to file homestead exemptions? Disabled, over 55 with SS income.
question: Became ill in 2012, loss job and have been unable to pay unsecured credit cards & medical bills. Only income is SS disability check . My plan is to file Bankruptcy as debts are $30K. No earned income since 2012. Disability covers basic expenses. I don't want trustee to force sale of home. Would like to file homestead exemption, bankruptcy and motions to vacate judgment. Is this a good plan.
answers:
No. Not too late to file Homestead Exemption.
Homestead automatic if BK is filed.

The homestead exemption is automatic in bankruptcy there is no need to file a declared homestead. When you file the bankruptcy you claim the automatic homestead exemption. Make sure you accurately value your home before you file so that you know all of the equity is in fact exempt.

Richard and Stuart have clearly shown that they know what they are talking about when dealing with problems like yours when considering bankruptcy issues in California. Please listen to him when he tells you how important it is to retain experienced bankruptcy counsel. You are dealing with your home, you need to make sure you do things the correct way.
As usual, atty Elie has covered your question with an outstanding analysis. I concur with his advice/

First of all let me say this much: If you file a homestead exemption form in public records, it will not preclude the creditors from forcing the sale of your home, nor the trustee in a Ch. 7. Here are the reasons why:

A. Your creditors ALREADY have judgments, so your homestead declaration will be subsequent in time to their judgments.

B. A homestead declaration filed prior to any judgments or subsequent non-consensual liens, only means you can sell your property despite the subsequent judgments and non-consensual liens and retain your exemption.

C. If you file a Ch. 7, the trustee becomes the hypothetical judgment lien creditor and can still compel the sale of your home. This is so because the homestead declaration is not absolute. And a Ch. 7 does not involve the consensual sale of your home. So filing one now won't do a bit of good.

Now for the important part. You have an automatic homestead exemption of $75k of your equity in the property. Equity means that the value of your home, less the mortgage balance and any resulting liens equals your equity. You may be entitled to an enhanced homestead exemption of up to $175,000.00 of your equity.

If a creditor/trustee seeks to levy on your home, you may assert your enhanced homestead exemption if you can establish you earn less than $35k per year as a married couple or $25k if you are unmarried. The enhanced exemption is up to $175,000.00. There is an intermediate amount of $100,000.00.

However, if you are unemployed, disabled and provably earning less than the minimum amount listed, then you probably qualify for the enhanced exemption.

That said, unless the creditor or trustee can prove that your equity exceeds the mortgage, and liens, its unlikely the trustee will try and sell the property.

Moreover, if there is any equity left in the property then the judgment liens will sail through and still remain attached to your homestead, subjecting it to a forced sale.

So this is the tricky part: if you want to keep your home, you may have to file a Ch. 13 rather than a Ch. 7.

I strongly suggest that you consult with and retain a seasoned bankruptcy lawyer in your area, rather than try and do this on your own. That's my suggestion.
